section.title: have got: positive form
section.sectiontitle: We use have got to talk about possessions/family. We use I/you/we/they have got. We usually use the short forms.
section.text1: I have got a dictionary with me.
section.text2: They have got a new telephone number.
section.sectiontitle2: We use he/she/it has got. We usually use the short forms.
section.text4: My computer has got a DVD player.

section.title: have got: negative form
section.sectiontitle: In the negative, we use I/you/we/they have not got.  We usually use the short forms.
section.text1: I have not got an e-mail address.
section.text2: We have not got a car.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use he/she/it has not got. We usually use the short forms.
section.text3: She has not got a camera.
section.text4: Paul has not got a girlfriend.

section.title: have got: question form
section.sectiontitle: In the question, we use have I/you/we/they got?
section.text1a: Have you got a mobile number? Yes, I have.
section.text2: They haven't got a pet cat.
section.text2a: Have they got a pet cat? No, they haven't.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we use has he/she/it got?
section.text3a: Has he got a watch? Yes, he has.
section.text4a: Has Sarah got a computer? No, she hasn't.
